content: The Act may be known as the "Teen Parent Graduation and College Achievement Act". Congress finds that the United States has the highest teenage pregnancy rate among industrialized nations, with nearly 750,000 American teenagers aged 15-19 becoming pregnant each year. While there has been a decline in teen pregnancy rates since the 1990s, rates increased in 2005-2006. Seventy percent of pregnant teenagers drop out of high school, with teenage fathers completing fewer semesters of high school compared to older fathers. Subsequent pregnancies can lead to more dropouts. Subsequent pregnancies accounted for 85,000, or almost 20 percent, of all teenage pregnancies. Marginalized racial or ethnic minority and immigrant communities have less access to education and support, leading to high rates of teenage pregnancy. This can result in a disproportionate dropout rate in these communities, with Latina and African-American teen girls having high pregnancy rates before the age of 20. Teenage pregnancy rates are higher among Latina and African-American youth aged 15-17 compared to Caucasian youth. Sexually active LGBTQ+ youth are three times more likely to experience unwanted pregnancies. Only 51% of teenage mothers have a high school diploma, leading to a high dropout rate among teenage women, with parenthood being a significant reason for dropping out. Teenage births are common among 18 and 19-year-olds, with higher rates among Latina and African-American women. Parenthood can hinder college graduation, with 61% of community college mothers not graduating compared to those without children. Increased support at higher education institutions, especially community colleges, could benefit older teenage parents. Comprehensive support from schools, public agencies, and community organizations can help reduce high school dropout rates for pregnant and parenting teenagers, ensuring they complete high school and pursue higher education. More data on the prevalence of teenage pregnancy is needed for targeted federal assistance in communities. The text chunk discusses the establishment of a grant program to assist pregnant and parenting students at elementary and secondary schools, with an authorized appropriation of $75,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2015. "Grant program established to assist pregnant and parenting students at schools, with $75,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2015." The Secretary will establish a grant program to help pregnant and parenting students stay in school by providing services such as tutoring, healthcare, child care, transportation, after-school support, academic counseling, and family planning services. Priority will be given to local educational agencies serving a significant percentage of pregnant and parenting students. The grant program aims to support pregnant and parenting students by providing services such as tutoring, healthcare, child care, transportation, after-school support, academic counseling, and family planning. The grant amount is capped at $500,000, with conditions including partnerships with public agencies or community-based organizations and limiting administrative costs to 10%. Grant funds can be used for various purposes to benefit pregnant and parenting students. The grant program allows funds to be used for compensating teachers and employees for additional services and supporting training practicums for graduate students in social work. Local educational agencies must submit an application to the Secretary to be eligible for the grant. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress on the program by September 30, 2013. The report submitted under the grant program must include information on the number and graduation rate of pregnant and parenting students benefiting from the program, their enrollment in higher education institutions, and the long-term effectiveness of the program in reducing costs to the Federal government. (b) Clerical Amendment.--The table of contents in section 2 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 6301 note) is amended by inserting after the item relating to section 1830 the following: "Grants for assistance to pregnant and parenting students at institutions of higher education are provided under a new subpart in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The grants aim to support pregnant and parenting students in their education." The Secretary will establish a grant program to help pregnant and parenting students in higher education by providing services like tutoring, healthcare, child care, transportation, and academic counseling. Priority will be given to institutions with a significant number of pregnant and parenting students. The grant program aims to support pregnant and parenting students in higher education by expanding access to services such as tutoring, healthcare, child care, transportation, and academic counseling. The grant amount is capped at $500,000, and institutions must partner with public agencies or community-based organizations to share funds. Additionally, no more than 10% of the grant can be used for administrative costs. The subsection (a) of the grant program allows for compensating teachers and encouraging training practicums for graduate students in social work. To be eligible for the grant, institutions of higher education must submit an application to the Secretary. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress on the program by specific dates. The report submitted under the grant program shall include information on the number and graduation rate of pregnant and parenting students benefiting from the program, as well as its long-term effectiveness in reducing costs to the Federal government.
